thread.title: Saudi businessman's cows being loaded on ship for China as approval pending
thread.title_full: Saudi businessman's cows being loaded on ship for China as approval pending

author: Gerard Hutching
title: Saudi businessman's cows being loaded on ship for China as approval pending
text:
Saudi businessman's cows being loaded on ship for China as approval pending GERARD HUTCHING Last updated 11:57, February 1 2017 SIMON HENDERY/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Awassi Express, owned by Saudi businessman Hmood Alali Al-Khalaf, docks at the Port of Napier on Tuesday. 
The 4500 dairy cows to be shipped to China by Saudi businessman Hmood Alali Al-Khalaf are being loaded on the Awassi Express in Napier on Wednesday, although the Government has yet to give approval for the shipment. 
Paul Dansted, director animal and animal products for the Ministry for Primary Industries, said no Animal Welfare Export Certificate (AWEC) would be issued until an MPI veterinarian was satisfied all animal welfare requirements had been met. 
These included adequate food, water, space, facilities and having suitably experienced stockmen and/or veterinarians on board for the journey. SCOTT HAMMOND/FAIRFAX NZ 
A holstein friesian, the type of dairy cow being shipped to China. 
"Exporters are expected to meet high standards to receive an AWEC," Dansted said. 
READ MORE: 5000 NZ dairy cows heading to China on Saudi businessman's ship 
In addition to the AWEC, a health certificate must be issued for the cattle. This certifies that the cattle meets China's import requirements including that they are negative for certain tests, have had the required treatments and met other health requirements. 
A spokesman for MPI minister Nathan Guy said the loading should be completed by today, and if the requirements were met, the AWEC would be signed off. 
The shipment is being managed by Australian company Landmark. In a statement, export manager Stephen Reynolds the shipment was a consignment of high quality holstein breeding heifers for an unnamed but large and well established dairy operation in China. 
He said three "very experienced stockmen" would accompany the animals. 
"The vessel is a recently converted livestock carrier built specifically for the Australian and New Zealand markets meeting the highest possible world standards as set by the Australian and New Zealand Maritime authorities for the carriage of live animals. Ad Feedback 
"Under the strict NZ government standards for the export of breeding livestock the vessel is capable of transporting in excess of 16,000 head of animals of the same weight category. This clearly allows the Landmark consignment to utilise additional space requirements as required to ensure the highest possible animal welfare outcome and comfort," Reynolds said. 
It had earlier been reported Al-Khalaf had applied to export 5300 cows, but an MPI spokesman said because MPI received applications in advance, the number of livestock on the application might change for a number of reasons. 
He said for a consignment of this size the cows would typically come from several hundred farms. 
Meanwhile Federated Farmers dairy group chairman Andrew Hoggard said he took issue with people who claimed New Zealand was losing out by sending its genetics to competitors like China. 
NZ First leader Winston Peters described it as "economic treason" and "short term thinking". 
But Hoggard said the cows were bred for New Zealand conditions and would not necessarily do well in an indoors operation. 
"It's being confused with the selling of apples and kiwifruit. These aren't cows that make a different kind of milk to anywhere else in the world and that give us a competitive advantage. 
"Our different breeding point is that we are breeding for cows that will do well on pasture, they are efficient producers based on that, but these going to China won't perform as well under the Chinese traditional barn system," Hoggard said. 
He also argued the Chinese were not getting the top performing cows. 
"Generally if you need 100-odd calves yourself and you've bred 130, you'd keep the top 100 for yourself and the bottom 30 are the ones you'd ship to China." 
New Zealand farmers received a "slight premium" to cows being sold on to the domestic market. 
Hoggard also questioned how long the cows would survive because of the greater number of diseases in China, such as foot and mouth. However, in recent years the skill level of animal husbandry had improved. 
He said it could be argued that the current practice of sending Kiwi cross genetics to Ireland was making the Irish more competitive against New Zealand in China, where the two countries compete for market share. - Stuff
